page.title: 13THE WORTH WAY
page.content: The Worth Way is the dismantled {railway line}between{Three Bridges}and {East Grinstead.}It opened in{1855}and closed in{1967.}It is about 8 miles long and had four stations; Three Bridges,{Rowfant, Grange Road (Crawley {Down)}and East Grinstead, which were built in 1855, except for Grange Road which was built in 1860. The{West Sussex County Council bought most of the line (but not the stations) and in{1976}the route was named Worth Way by{Crawley Down Church {of England School,}as the result of a competition. The Worth Way is now a {linear country park.}It is a{public {footpath}and{bridleway}and is linked to the{Forest Way}in{East Sussex. Ponds have been established along it which encourage{wildlife.}It is known for the variety of wild{orchids} growing along it.
